name: Chevening Scholarship (UK Government)
deadline_note: Many 2026–27 Chevening calls list early-October deadlines (for example, 7 October 2025 in recent regional calls); applicants must check the official Chevening website for exact dates.
description_raw: Chevening Scholarships are fully funded one-year master’s awards for emerging leaders from Chevening-eligible countries to study any subject at a UK university. The scholarship typically covers full tuition fees, a monthly living stipend, travel to and from the UK, visa costs, and additional allowances, and provides access to a global leadership and alumni network.

name: Vanier Canada Graduate Scholarships (Vanier CGS)

description_raw: The Vanier Canada Graduate Scholarships program helps Canadian institutions attract and retain world-class doctoral students. description_raw: The Pierre Elliott Trudeau Foundation Doctoral Scholarship is a three-year leadership programme for doctoral candidates in the social sciences and humanities who are engaging with themes related to human rights and dignity, responsible citizenship, Canada and the world, or people and their natural environment. Scholars receive substantial funding for tuition and living costs plus an annual allowance for research and language-learning activities, alongside intensive leadership training and mentorship.
eligibility_raw: Applicants must be enrolled in or accepted to a full-time doctoral program (or combined MA/PhD) in the social sciences or humanities at a Canadian university, or Canadians pursuing such study abroad. They should have completed or be in their first or second year of doctoral study in the competition year. Candidates must demonstrate outstanding academic achievement, leadership and engagement in communities, and a strong fit with the Foundation’s themes and leadership curriculum. Both Canadian and international students may be eligible under specific conditions outlined by the Foundation.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe your doctoral research project, how it relates to one or more of the Foundation’s themes, and why it matters for society.
Tell a story about a concrete moment when you exercised leadership or took a stand in your community. What did you learn about yourself and others?
Explain how the Foundation’s leadership programme, cohort model, and mentorship network would shape your development as an engaged scholar-leader.

name: Fulbright Foreign Student Program
provider_name: U.S. Department of State – Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs
deadline_note: Application deadlines are set by each participating country and typically fall between May and June, with application portals opening around February for many countries.
description_raw: The Fulbright Foreign Student Program enables graduate students, young professionals, and artists from over 160 countries to study or conduct research in the United States. Awards are generally fully funded and can cover tuition, living stipend, travel, health benefits, and other expenses. The program emphasises academic merit, cultural exchange, and potential for leadership and mutual understanding.
eligibility_raw: Eligibility varies by country and is administered by national Fulbright Commissions or U.S. Embassies. In general, applicants must reside in their country of citizenship at the time of application, hold at least the equivalent of a U.S. bachelor’s degree with strong academic performance, be proficient in English, and not hold U.S. citizenship. Each country may specify additional field priorities, funding details, and timelines. Applicants compete for nomination in their home country and then for placement at U.S. institutions.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe your proposed field of study or research in the United States and how it will contribute to your academic and professional goals.
Explain how you have engaged in your community or profession and how participation in the Fulbright Program would allow you to deepen your contributions.
Discuss how you will help promote mutual understanding between your home country and the United States during and after your grant.

name: Commonwealth Shared Scholarship
provider_name: Commonwealth Scholarship Commission in the UK (CSC)
deadline_note: University and CSC pages for the 2026–27 entry list scholarship application deadlines around 9 December 2025 at 16:00 GMT; exact timelines and eligible courses depend on the partner university.
description_raw: Commonwealth Shared Scholarships are for candidates from eligible low- and middle-income Commonwealth countries to study selected one-year taught master’s courses at UK universities. The awards are co-funded by the UK’s Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office and participating universities, and usually cover full tuition fees, approved airfare, a living allowance, and additional allowances.
eligibility_raw: Applicants must be citizens of, or have been granted refugee status by, an eligible Commonwealth country and be permanently resident in such a country. They must be available to start academic studies in the UK by the beginning of the relevant academic year, hold at least an upper second-class honours degree (or equivalent), and be unable to afford study in the UK without the scholarship. Eligible master’s programmes are in development-related fields aligned with CSC development themes (such as science and technology for development, health systems, prosperity, governance, crisis response, and inclusion). Applications are submitted both to the university and via the CSC online system.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe how your chosen master’s course relates to one of the Commonwealth Scholarship Commission’s development themes and the needs of your home country.
Explain your financial circumstances and why you would be unable to study in the UK without this scholarship.
Outline your plans to apply the skills and knowledge gained in the UK to contribute to development in your country or region after graduation.

name: Knight-Hennessy Scholars at Stanford University
deadline_note: Knight-Hennessy application deadlines for the 2026 cohort fall in early October 2025, several weeks before most underlying Stanford program deadlines; exact dates are published each cycle.
description_raw: Knight-Hennessy Scholars is a fully funded graduate scholarship at Stanford University for emerging global leaders across all disciplines. Scholars receive funding for up to three years of graduate study, including tuition, a stipend for living and academic expenses, and a travel grant for one annual trip to and from Stanford. The program includes a multidisciplinary leadership development curriculum and a diverse cohort intentionally selected from around the world.
eligibility_raw: Applicants from any country may apply. They must also apply separately to and be admitted by a full-time Stanford graduate degree program. In general, applicants must have earned their first bachelor’s degree within a specified recent time window (for example, January 2018 through September 2025 for the 2026 cohort, with an extension for some military applicants). Selection emphasizes independence of thought, purposeful leadership, and a civic mindset, assessed through academic records, recommendations, essays, and a video or in-person assessment.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe the experiences and values that have most shaped your ambitions and the kind of leader you aspire to be.
Tell us about a time you pursued an unconventional path, challenged a prevailing view, or took a principled risk. What happened and what did you learn?
Explain how your proposed Stanford program and the Knight-Hennessy community together will help you create impact at scale.

name: Schwarzman Scholars Program
deadline_note: For the class entering 2027–2028, global and U.S. applicant deadlines typically fall in early to mid-September of the previous year, with slightly different dates for Chinese passport holders; confirm exact deadlines each cycle.
description_raw: Schwarzman Scholars is a fully funded one-year master’s program in Global Affairs at Tsinghua University in Beijing designed to prepare future leaders for roles in geopolitics, business, and civil society. The scholarship covers tuition and fees, room and board, travel to and from Beijing, in-country study tours, required course materials, and a stipend for personal expenses.
eligibility_raw: Candidates must be between 18 and 28 or 29 years of age (depending on the entry year definition), have completed a bachelor’s degree before the program start date, and demonstrate strong English proficiency. Applicants from any country and academic background are welcome, though they must show outstanding academic achievement, leadership potential, and a record of initiative and impact. Separate application timelines and procedures exist for international applicants and for those holding passports from the People’s Republic of China.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe a leadership experience where you brought together people with different perspectives to address a complex challenge.
Explain how studying Global Affairs in China through the Schwarzman Scholars program fits into your long-term vision for impact.
Reflect on a moment that significantly changed how you view global issues, power, or cooperation.
